articles.headline: Trump Urged Homeland Security Official to Close Border Despite an Earlier Promise of a Delay
articles.snippet: The conversation with Kevin McAleenan was another instance of the president trying to undo a decision and to stretch the boundaries of his power, even when told there were legal issues at stake.
articles.abstract: The conversation with Kevin McAleenan was another instance of the president trying to undo a decision and to stretch the boundaries of his power, even when told there were legal issues at stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump last week privately urged Kevin McAleenan, the border enforcement official he was about to name as acting secretary of homeland security, to close the southwestern border to migrants despite having just said publicly that he was delaying a decision on the step for a year, according to three people briefed about the conversation.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Annie Karni and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Your Student Loan Servicer Will Call You Back in a Year. Sorry.
articles.snippet: Many public servants in the federal loan forgiveness program spot errors in the count of their qualifying payments. Their servicer tells them reviews will take a while.
articles.abstract: Many public servants in the federal loan forgiveness program spot errors in the count of their qualifying payments. Their servicer tells them reviews will take a while.
articles.lead_paragraph: The emails started arriving in my inbox from borrowers in the federal Public Service Loan Forgiveness program in late February. Their states of residence — Tennessee, California, Michigan — were all different. So were their jobs — teacher, doctor, member of the military.

articles.headline: As Ecuador Harbored Assange, It Was Subjected to Threats and Leaks
articles.snippet: The Ecuadorean Embassy in London protected the WikiLeaks founder from prosecution for years, but its tolerance wore thin.
articles.abstract: The Ecuadorean Embassy in London protected the WikiLeaks founder from prosecution for years, but its tolerance wore thin.
articles.lead_paragraph: The secrets came directly from the phones of President Lenín Moreno of Ecuador: intimate pictures of him and his family on vacation, text messages from his wife, even a photograph of the president himself in a posh bedroom, eating a lobster in bed.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Hollywood Upended as Unions Tell Writers to Fire Agents
articles.snippet: Talks between TV and movie writers and their agencies on a new code of conduct broke off before a midnight deadline. “It has become clear a big change is necessary,” the Writers Guild of America said.
articles.abstract: Talks between TV and movie writers and their agencies on a new code of conduct broke off before a midnight deadline. “It has become clear a big change is necessary,” the Writers Guild of America said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fire your agents.

articles.headline: Central American Farmers Head to the U.S., Fleeing Climate Change
articles.snippet: The problems plaguing farmers in Honduras and elsewhere have mounted with rising temperatures and increasingly unpredictable weather.
articles.abstract: The problems plaguing farmers in Honduras and elsewhere have mounted with rising temperatures and increasingly unpredictable weather.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORQUÍN, Honduras — The farmer stood in his patch of forlorn coffee plants, their leaves sick and wilted, the next harvest in doubt.

articles.headline: The Many Reasons to Run for President When You Probably Don’t Stand a Chance
articles.snippet: There are book deals and TV contracts and maybe a cabinet position if your side wins. Recent history suggests there is almost no downside to giving it a shot.
articles.abstract: There are book deals and TV contracts and maybe a cabinet position if your side wins. Recent history suggests there is almost no downside to giving it a shot.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no discernible mass groundswell for an Eric Swalwell presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Tracking Phones, Google Is a Dragnet for the Police
articles.snippet: The tech giant records people’s locations worldwide. Now, investigators are using it to find suspects and witnesses near crimes, running the risk of snaring the innocent.
articles.abstract: The tech giant records people’s locations worldwide. Now, investigators are using it to find suspects and witnesses near crimes, running the risk of snaring the innocent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tech giant records people’s locations worldwide. Now, investigators are using it to find suspects and witnesses near crimes, running the risk of snaring the innocent.

articles.headline: Trump’s Fury vs. Shaky Markets: Jerome Powell’s Balancing Act as Fed Chief
articles.snippet: How Jerome H. Powell handles the next few months will be a critical test of his leadership skills, as he tries to guide the bank through a highly uncertain moment in the global economy.
articles.abstract: How Jerome H. Powell handles the next few months will be a critical test of his leadership skills, as he tries to guide the bank through a highly uncertain moment in the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As soon as the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome H. Powell, finished speaking at his December news conference, it was clear, even to him, that he had blown it. Stocks were tumbling. Analysts worried that the Fed was steering the economy into recession.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Neil Irwin

articles.headline: Apple and Qualcomm’s Global Fight Heads to Court in San Diego
articles.snippet: The battle between the companies, once partners, could affect the division of billions of dollars in smartphone profits and, perhaps, how much consumers pay for phones.
articles.abstract: The battle between the companies, once partners, could affect the division of billions of dollars in smartphone profits and, perhaps, how much consumers pay for phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nasty legal battles are nothing new in the tech industry. But Apple’s conflict with the wireless chip maker Qualcomm, headed for a crucial court showdown this coming week, has a special intensity.

articles.headline: Pete Buttigieg’s Focus: Storytelling First. Policy Details Later.
articles.snippet: In his writings as a student and young politician, he fixated on the kind of media narratives that have propelled his 2020 campaign.
articles.abstract: In his writings as a student and young politician, he fixated on the kind of media narratives that have propelled his 2020 campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: The question was simple enough, but Senator John Edwards squirmed painfully. For 49 long seconds, the North Carolina Democrat, a masterful courtroom orator, sputtered before a crowd at Harvard, unable to settle on a favorite movie.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Accuses Liberal Think Tank of Smearing Progressive Candidates
articles.snippet: The Vermont senator’s criticism of the Center for American Progress threatens to inflame the ideological divisions that roiled the Democratic Party in 2016.
articles.abstract: The Vermont senator’s criticism of the Center for American Progress threatens to inflame the ideological divisions that roiled the Democratic Party in 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bernie Sanders, in a rare and forceful rebuke by a presidential candidate of an influential party ally, has accused a liberal think tank of undermining Democrats’ chances of taking back the White House in 2020 by “using its resources to smear” him and other contenders pushing progressive policies.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: One Month, 500,000 Face Scans: How China Is Using A.I. to Profile a Minority
articles.snippet: In a major ethical leap for the tech world, Chinese start-ups have built algorithms that the government uses to track members of a largely Muslim minority group.
articles.abstract: In a major ethical leap for the tech world, Chinese start-ups have built algorithms that the government uses to track members of a largely Muslim minority group.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese government has drawn wide international condemnation for its harsh crackdown on ethnic Muslims in its western region, including holding as many as a million of them in detention camps.

articles.headline: Face It: You (Probably) Got a Tax Cut
articles.snippet: Studies consistently find that the 2017 law cut taxes for most Americans. Most of them don’t buy it.
articles.abstract: Studies consistently find that the 2017 law cut taxes for most Americans. Most of them don’t buy it.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re an American taxpayer, you probably got a tax cut last year. And there’s a good chance you don’t believe it.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Shocked by Your Tax Refund? Next Year Could Be Worse Unless You Act Now
articles.snippet: Fewer taxpayers have received refunds so far this year, and refunds are smaller. Now is the time to check your paycheck withholdings.
articles.abstract: Fewer taxpayers have received refunds so far this year, and refunds are smaller. Now is the time to check your paycheck withholdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Conor Barnes, an accountant in New York, decided to stop telling her clients to “have a nice day” at the end of their meetings. Often she delivered news that had, in fact, ruined their day: They owed the government money, sometimes a painfully large amount.

articles.headline: ISIS Kidnapped Her 5 Years Ago. The Red Cross Thinks She May Still Be Alive.
articles.snippet: The abduction of Louisa Akavi, a nurse from New Zealand, was kept secret for years. Now the aid group is breaking its silence in hopes of saving her.
articles.abstract: The abduction of Louisa Akavi, a nurse from New Zealand, was kept secret for years. Now the aid group is breaking its silence in hopes of saving her.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, employees of the International Committee of the Red Cross have made weekly visits to a detention camp in northern Syria bearing a photograph of a petite woman in her early 60s.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Trump Sees an Obstacle to Getting His Way on Immigration: His Own Officials
articles.snippet: The president’s removal of Department of Homeland Security officials was the culmination of months of clashes over policies many say were legally dubious, unethical or impractical.
articles.abstract: The president’s removal of Department of Homeland Security officials was the culmination of months of clashes over policies many say were legally dubious, unethical or impractical.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen Miller was furious — again.
articles.byline: By Eileen Sullivan and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: In Search for Leverage, Trump May Be Undercutting His Own Trade Deals
articles.snippet: President Trump’s unpredictable style has brought foreign countries to the negotiating table. But will it result in the United States leaving with more?
articles.abstract: President Trump’s unpredictable style has brought foreign countries to the negotiating table. But will it result in the United States leaving with more?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is embracing a new tactic as he tries to rewrite the rules of global trade: Don’t believe a final deal is truly final.

articles.headline: What’s a Feminist Government? Canada, and Trudeau, Grapple With the Question
articles.snippet: Accusations by Canada’s former attorney general have propelled the country into an agonized and occasionally hairsplitting argument about feminism in political life.
articles.abstract: Accusations by Canada’s former attorney general have propelled the country into an agonized and occasionally hairsplitting argument about feminism in political life.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — It was the sort of audience meant to be a natural fit for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada — more than 300 young women taking part in a “Daughters of the Vote” day of civic engagement in Parliament. But no sooner had he begun to speak than several dozen of the women stood up and dramatically turned their backs on him.

articles.headline: In Attacking Ilhan Omar, Trump Revives His Familiar Refrain Against Muslims
articles.snippet: The president hopes to resurrect a major theme of his 2016 campaign for his re-election bid in 2020. This time, he has picked a specific target.
articles.abstract: The president hopes to resurrect a major theme of his 2016 campaign for his re-election bid in 2020. This time, he has picked a specific target.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has often seen the political benefits of stigmatizing Muslims.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Big Companies Thought Insurance Covered a Cyberattack. They May Be Wrong.
articles.snippet: Citing a rarely used ‘war exemption,’ insurers say they aren’t responsible for the 2017 NotPetya attack.
articles.abstract: Citing a rarely used ‘war exemption,’ insurers say they aren’t responsible for the 2017 NotPetya attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Within days of a cyberattack, warehouses of the snack foods company Mondelez International filled with a backlog of Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Former VW C.E.O. Martin Winterkorn Is Charged by Germany in Diesel Scheme
articles.snippet: Prosecutors in Germany connected the charges against Martin Winterkorn and four other managers to events that ran from 2006, when the diesel scandal was first conceived, to 2015.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors in Germany connected the charges against Martin Winterkorn and four other managers to events that ran from 2006, when the diesel scandal was first conceived, to 2015.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German prosecutors on Monday filed aggravated fraud charges against Martin Winterkorn, the former chief executive of Volkswagen who led the company when it deceived regulators about its vehicles’ diesel exhaust levels.
